title: New York City's Economy Grew at 3% Rate in First Quarter, Report Finds
summary: Average unemployment claims decreased 6.4% since the previous quarter. New York City's economy remained strong in the first quarter of the year, buoyed by record-low unemployment, according to a report by Comptroller Scott Stringer.

summary: Small lenders in particular face hurdles when it comes to attracting staff to manage anti-money-laundering compliance programs. title: Making Room for Airbnb

summary: Bonds also struggle despite CEO Elon Musk's efforts to reassure investors. Tesla Inc. shares touched their lowest level in more than two years as prices on its bonds also slumped, a sign of investors' growing doubts about the car maker's outlook.

title: Guatemalan Boy Dies in U.S. Border Patrol Custody

title: On Trade, Where Are My Fellow Democrats?
summary: They should oppose Trump's destructive tariffs and support U.S. exporters.. President Trump's latest round of punishing tariffs on China, with threats of more to come, will have a devastating effect on the world's two largest economies. His actions are contrary to the Republican Party's usual doctrine of free trade, and they have alarmed business leaders, farmers and the American sectors and regions that will most acutely feel the pain of the tariff increases and China's targeted retaliation.

title: New York's Subsidy for Striking Unions
summary: Walk off the job and get unemployment benefits after a week.. Unemployment insurance programs are meant to help people who become jobless through no fault of their own. Nearly every state has disallowed benefits to employees who are on strike. Even New York, the most union-friendly state, pays unemployment benefits to strikers only in rare instances when they have been out of work for at least eight weeks.

title: 'The Tatas' Review: The Mogul's Empire
summary: The Indian conglomerate Tata Group, founded in the mid-19th century, has had an outsize effect on the country's aspiring middle class.. John D. Rockefeller Sr. and Jamsetji Tata were born four months apart in 1839. From Richford, N.Y., and Gujarat, modern India's westernmost state, they would become two of the greatest business dynasts the world has ever known, founders of Standard Oil and the behemoth conglomerate Tata Group, still controlled by Tata's descendants. Yet their paths to riches, some 7,500 miles apart, were paved differently. Rockefeller made his fortune through integrating businesses, Tata by creating them; Rockefeller flourished at the cutting edge of the Second Industrial Revolution, Tata under Great Britain's imperial thumb; Rockefeller lives on in Ron Chernow's exemplary 1998 biography, "Titan," while Tata (1839-1904) and his successors are shrouded in myth and corporate propaganda. Girish Kuber's "The Tatas: How a Family Built a Business and a Nation" is an affectionate variation on the latter.

title: Not Every Officer Wants to Be a General
summary: Allowing service members to pursue different career paths would ease the strain on military families.. A chronic problem has attracted bipartisan attention recently: Military spouses have trouble finding work or developing careers. Karen Pence, the vice president's wife, has devoted much of her public profile to helping military spouses. Sens. Tom Cotton and Jeanne Shaheen have introduced a bill that aims to make it easier for military spouses to transfer occupational licenses across state lines, which would mitigate one hassle of moving. But the real problem is a military assignment system that is managed like a game of musical chairs.

title: Court Rules Judge, Not Jury, Should Decide Merck Fosamax Case

WASHINGTON- Merck & Co. won a partial victory at the Supreme Court, with the justices unanimously ruling that a judge, rather than a jury, must determine whether federal regulators took steps that immunize the company from claims its osteoporosis drug Fosamax injured patients.

title: Huawei Is an Asset, Not a Threat

Vilified as a cat's-paw of the Chinese government, Mr. Ren has decided to place his trust in America's legal system and launch a court challenge to the U.S. government's campaign against his company-and family. His daughter, Huawei chief financial officer Meng Wanzhou, is fighting extradition to the U.S. from Canada on murky charges that she helped financial institutions violate American sanctions on Iran. She has been under house arrest in Vancouver, British Columbia, since December.

title: 'Rocketman' Review: A Biopic Blasts Off
summary: Taron Egerton stars in Dexter Fletcher's film about the music icon's breakout years.. Much of the bountiful pleasure of "Rocketman," a jukebox musical about the genesis, emergence and turbulent triumph of a self-creation named Elton John, comes from the film's delight in embellishing its subject's embellishments, gilding its legendary lily. The events of his breakthrough years are heightened with fantasy sequences that amount to a swirling, semi-surreal remix of his career and inner life. The colors are stunning, the settings are striking and the energy is irresistible, even if the pop psychologizing is pretty glib. Yet this gorgeously preposterous phantasmagoria wouldn't hold us as it does if it weren't based on something real and true, and two realities operate in tandem-the songs, whose beauty and power have only been amplified by the passage of time; and a starring performance of dazzling audacity by Taron Egerton, who evokes the great man without falling back on mimicry. Mr. Egerton's singing and dancing, as well as his nuanced acting, are entirely convincing, yet a distinctive creation of his own.

title: Traditional Medicare Has Certain Advantages
summary: Most of us prefer to select our own physicians.. In his May 15 op-ed "Medicare Isn't All It's Cracked Up to Be," Chris Pope seems to have missed the main reason why Americans reject Medicare Advantage plans in favor of original or traditional Medicare. I would suggest that most of us prefer to select our own physicians. The fact is that Medicare Advantage plans may cost the consumer less, but they provide you with a preselected list of doctors and other health-care providers. You choose only from their network. Most often, you also need to get a referral from your primary-care doctor to see a specialist.

title: The U.S. Bears No Blame as Cuba Starves on Its Policies
summary: Today, less than 25% of Cuba's arable land is in cultivation.. Regarding "Cuba to Ration Sales of Basic Food Items" (World News, May 13), Cuba's Commerce Minister Betsy Diaz asserts that the U.S. embargo forces the island to buy food from distant markets, which raises prices. The "distant markets" for about 75% of Cuba's food imports are actually in the U.S. The embargo, such as it is, requires such sales to be on a cash basis. Credit sales are denied so as to prevent Cuba from stiffing U.S. suppliers, as it has done with all its other trading partners.

title: PG&E Finger-Pointing Is Counterproductive

Earlier this year, the company filed for bankruptcy after being mired in legal uncertainty from the incident.

title: Better Gadgets Don't Equal a Better Standard of Living
summary: Though a larger TV may pack more value for its price, it doesn't increase a consumer's productivity.. Andy Kessler's column "The Fed Is Flying Blind on Inflation" overstates technology's impact on aggregate consumer-price inflation (Inside View, May 13). The problem with the hedonic-adjusted prices is that the increased quality assumed by the government may offer only marginal benefit to the end-user or consumer. The Bureau of Labor Statistics likely overstates the quality adjustment captured by the aggregate consumer.

title: Grim Memories of a Pre-Vaccinated World
summary: My two older brothers and sister had polio in the 1940s.. title: Hate Buying Cleaning Supplies? There's a Pill for That
summary: The war on straws may have captured our eco-imaginations, but giant plastic jugs of bleach, window cleaner and counter spray are worse, says Sarah Paiji Yoo. What if all you needed to clean your house was a tablet the size of an Alka-Seltzer?. In 2017, ahead of her first business trip since giving birth to her son, entrepreneur Sarah Paiji Yoo was doing research on how to switch him to formula. When she came across studies of microplastics in our water supply, she grew concerned about her family's health and decided to start limiting her plastic consumption. She quickly ran into hurdles in her household shopping. Shampoo, window glass cleaner, mouthwash-almost all the products she needed came packaged in plastic. "I was looking at cleaning sprays and realized they're like 90% water," she says. "Why am I buying a new plastic bottle every time? Why can't we make these parts in a powder or a tablet?"

title: Amid the Fog, Trump's Real Agenda in Iran
summary: U.S. president uses economic sanctions to generate unprecedented pressure on Iran, with two apparent goals in mind. Whatever other assets and liabilities he brings to the table, President Trump certainly offers this: He is a master at sowing uncertainty, so neither friend nor foe really knows what he's up to.

title: 5 Ways to Wear High-Contrast Black and White
summary: Opposites attract with this graphic style, here seen on shoes, bags and coats. How to wear black and white from head to toe. A pointed toe is a sharp choice. $645, pierrehardy.com

title: Meet Booksmart's Beanie Feldstein, Jonah Hill's Brilliantly Funny Sister
summary: Following her supporting role in 2017's 'Lady Bird,' Beanie Feldstein is front and center in Olivia Wilde's directorial debut, 'Booksmart'. The film Booksmart begins with a close-up of Beanie Feldstein, as Molly, the valedictorian of her high school class. She glowers, with her jaw clenched and eyes closed, as she prepares for a final day in the trenches with her fellow (and supposedly inferior) classmates. They partied instead of studying and won't be going to Yale, like her.

title: The Slugger Who Is Conjuring Ted Williams
summary: Dodgers star Cody Bellinger used to only hit home runs. Now he is hitting over .400.. LOS ANGELES-The last seven-plus decades of baseball's history suggest that Cody Bellinger probably won't hit .400 this year. Since the legendary Ted Williams last accomplished the feat in 1941, only two players have managed to even reach .390: George Brett for the Kansas City Royals in 1980 and Tony Gwynn for the San Diego Padres in the strike-shortened 1994 campaign. Since then, nobody has posted a batting average better than .379.

title: In the Game of Planes, You Lose or You Become Less Low-Cost
summary: Ryanair's commitment to aggressive expansion despite weaker profits could bring in rewards in time, but also increases its cost base. Those mourning the end of HBO's hit show "Game of Thrones" can always watch the cutthroat world of European airlines. Budget leader Ryanair wants to keep its crown by expanding as aggressively as possible, but the strategy is bringing higher costs-a problem for a low-cost operation.

title: Volatility Is Here to Stay, Some Investors Wager
summary: Renewed trade worries have many market participants positioning for more turbulence. A growing number of investors are betting that markets will stay erratic as a renewed bout of trade worries roils global stocks.

title: Deutsche Bank Shares Hit All-Time Low
summary: Fresh investor doubts emerge over investment bank and broader strategy ahead of German lender's annual meeting. Deutsche Bank AG's shares traded at an all-time low Monday just weeks after talks with Commerzbank AG failed. Now bank officials, facing fresh investor doubts about the lender's ailing investment bank and overall strategy, are bracing for a barrage of criticism from shareholders at the bank's annual meeting Thursday in Frankfurt.

title: Toshiba Memory to Buy Out Shares From Apple, Dell
summary: They are among the four U.S. companies set to give up their shares for more than $4 billion under a refinancing plan. TOKYO- Apple Inc., Dell Technologies Inc. and two other U.S. technology companies are set to give up their preferred shares in Japanese chip maker Toshiba Memory Holdings Corp. for more than $4 billion under a refinancing plan, according to people familiar with the plan.

title: Pimco's Ties to Architect of College-Admissions Scam Ran Deep
summary: Before ex-CEO Douglas Hodge turned to William 'Rick' Singer, another executive at the bond giant had recommended the admission counselor's services. NEWPORT BEACH, Calif.-Pacific Investment Management Co. is facing its most turbulent stretch in five years.

title: Forced Tech Transfers Are on the Rise in China, European Firms Say
summary: The practice has become more widespread despite official assurances from Beijing it would be stopped. European businesses in China say forced technology transfers to local firms have become more common over the past two years as foreign firms battle for access in the world's second-largest economy.

title: Sweden Moves Toward Issuing Arrest Warrant for Assange
summary: The Swedish move marks the latest turn the long-running saga of a man the U.S. says ran a hostile foreign-intelligence service. STOCKHOLM-Sweden took the first formal steps toward requesting the extradition of Julian Assange, in what is likely to be a protracted battle to bring the WikiLeaks founder to trial.

title: Japan Surprises With 2.1% Growth, but It's Not All Roses
summary: Growth in public investment drove economic expansion in the first quarter, overcoming the impact of U.S.-China trade tensions. TOKYO-The Japanese economy unexpectedly grew in the first quarter of 2019 supported by government spending, although there were some worrying signs connected to the U.S.-China trade dispute.

title: Dollar Weakens on Trade Tensions
summary: Investors track latest developments in trade conflict between the U.S. and China. The dollar fell Monday, as investors tracked the latest developments in the trade conflict between the U.S. and China.

title: A Gift to Morehouse Class of 2019: Your Student Loans Are Gone
summary: Billionaire Robert F. Smith made announcement during his keynote speech at commencement. ATLANTA-The keynote speaker for Morehouse College's commencement ceremony on Sunday caused elation when he made a stunning announcement: The billionaire would pay off the college debt of every graduate in the class.

title: Economic Fears Drove Australia's Surprise Election Result
summary: Scott Morrison prevailed in battleground states where voters feared his opponent's policies would threaten jobs. SYDNEY-Australian conservative Prime Minister Scott Morrison's surprise come-from-behind win in national elections was fueled by a campaign that focused on fears that economic and climate policies pledged by center-left opponents would end the world's longest growth streak.
